description.text:
I designed this a few weeks ago, but I wasn't able to print it successfully because of massive warping of the printed ABS.
Since I've recently pimped up my MakerBot with a heated build platform, warping of ABS isn't an issue anymore!
That said, be sure to print this either with a very strong raft, with PLA or with a heated build surface... You'll need a standard iPod/iPhone 30-pin-connector/USB cable for this.

• Print the object
  • Put the 30-pin connector thru the hole in the bottom.
  • Insert the connector in the cut-out. It's a tight fit. Please don't damage your cable or the connector during this process.
  • Insert the cable in the groove on the bottom.

comments.text: Tried to build on Replicator 2X, using white ABS, medium quality, heated build plate with and without a raft. Both prints failed. The start of the print seems 'faulty' as it does not lay down the first layer on the build plate / raft but several mm in the air!

author: Drcashman

description.text: A support for 5 files, with two holes to screw it to a wall.

Mounts directly on top of any standard longboard/skateboard truck baseplate (drop-through decks), or on top of the deck above the truck (top-mounted decks). You may need longer screws than what you are currently using. Fits the GoPro quick release clip. Note: I haven't had a chance to physically make one yet, but once I have I will tweak the design as needed to increase performance. Update 01/20/16: I've uploaded two newer designs, one for each kind of screw that is commonly used for mounting skate trucks to a board: pan-head screws and chamfered screws.
Update 01/28/16: Yesterday I finished machining my first prototype. Hopefully I'll be able to test it soon so I can make any necessary modifications. All improved designs will be uploaded once they are generated.
Update 01/29/16: All files have been updated to include recent design modifications.

Here is a pair-of-pants surface designed for the InforMath project funded by the National Science Foundation (DRL-1323587). The InforMath project (http://informalmathematics.org/) is a partnership between San Diego State University and several museums at the Balboa Park, including the Reuben H. Fleet Science Center (http://www.rhfleet.org/) These models are designed to join together using small magnets. There are two options for the print files, ones with small holes for the magnets and ones without. There is a ring system too, so that you have more flexibility in how the models are put together. There are also thin versions of the models (with no magnet holes). More information about the models, including how they were designed can be found at http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2016/02/09/constructing-a-pair-of-pants/ and http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2016/02/09/pair-of-pants-surfaces-the-math/.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: The models are sized to fit in your hand. You may have to scale by a factor of 10 if you're using MakerWare, since it tends to import files in mm, not cm. I printed without a raft, but with extra strong supports. The standard supports tended to be knocked around by the printer nozzle. Under Print Settings, go to Custom, then Supports and Bridging. Check the Supports box, then uncheck the Align Supports box.

The pair-of-pants, caps, etc are held together by 3mm (diameter) x 3mm (height) cylindrical rare earth magnets (http://www.gaussboys.com/store/index.php/magnet-shapes/cylinders/c0303.html). The magnets should fit snugly, and I didn't need any glue. If you do, you could try using a little JB Weld epoxy just in case. I suspect that you could also use superglue. I highly recommend printing DesignByNumber's magnet insertion tools (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:436565) to help seat the magnets into the little holes. For the pair-of-pants and caps models, I alternated the + and – ends of magnets around the rims of the pair-of-pants. I did this in a consistent way, for example the + was always at the front and back of the pants. For the rings, the plain ones should be aligned the same alternating way on the top and bottom rims. The ones with plus/minus signs or 90 degrees should have the arrangement rotated by 90 degrees. The Rueben H. Fleet Science Museum in San Diego made the body of the regular and bent pair of pants be +, then made all the rings -. Not sure what they did with the caps, probably made them all + too. This keeps it very simple.

A complete description can be found on my blog at http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2016/02/09/constructing-a-pair-of-pants/ A very brief description of the mathematics can be found here: http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2016/02/09/pair-of-pants-surfaces-the-math/

comments.text: Thank you. I created them to illustrate a concept from topology: Any orientable surface of genus at least 2 may be decomposed into a sum of pairs of pants. Check out https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pair_of_pants_(mathematics). These models were printed and displayed in the Fleet Science Center in San Diego, as part of the (now closed) Taping Shape exhibit there.
comments.author: dennedesigns

comments.text: Its a pretty neat shape.  In fact, somehow it seems that it should prove very useful in some context, but I'm not sure what.  Its just a gut feeling.  They're not exactly "The Wrong Trousers" :-)  I would have been tempted to build this using OpenScad, boolean adding together a bunch of 30 degree torus sections and then boolean subtracting out paths similarly.  The shape would not be quite the same.  Nothing would be squarish, which may have been desirable here.  It would be fun to make the legs half the size and generate an n level fractal with poly-trousers with 4, 8, 16, 32.... leg holes.  Again, I'm not sure what one would do with such a manifold, but something may come to mind to someone. :-)  Perhaps it would be enough for it to be fun to look at.  Not everything has to have a utilitarian purpose.  :-)
comments.author: foxpup

description.text:
This scale model of the ubiquitous 55 gallon oil drum has many potential uses.  It can be simply a closed container on a shipping dock as modeled in the second image.  It can be a fluid dispenser in on the shop floor for multiple possible liquids as in the featured model. And it can be emptied as a trash can as in the third model. Homeless people sometimes use it as a fire pit, Kids and Circus performers (even lions) can use them on their sides for rolling!  
I'm sure I will come up with a number of ways to employ these models in my dioramas.

Here is another guitar stand. THIS one I actually designed myself, unlike the others I previously uploaded. It's a beginner project for me and I think it worked out pretty well. I recently updated this with a holder that goes along the front because I had originally used duct tape and it was ugly.  
Also works with a bass guitar.

There's 2 feet, two top halves, and 1 holder, though you can print two holders if you like. I found that the feet are flush only facing one direction when attaching to top halves. Also, the holder can go several ways but I found putting it around the screw holes rather than on the inner part held the stand tighter. Otherwise, the guitar feet are too far apart and my guitar slides around too much. You will need five makerbolts http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095 or something comparable to hold the five connections together.

comments.text: re how to assemble the pieces: Why not just use glue on the legs connecting to the outside triangles, and a strong clip on to bind the top. As for the spacer, seems like strong clips would work there as well instead of screws; like the kind used to bind a small stack of papers with the metal fold down arms. I will be making this!

description.text: A two-part button with magnets that snaps over accessory cables to secure their loose ends to a metal object.

Printed in ABS with 0.25mm layer height and 0.4mm nozzle diameter.   
Uses 1/4" x 1/10" rare-earth disk magnets.  If a press-fit is too loose, then put a drop of super glue on the back of the magnet so that it wicks into the gaps without causing a mess on the front face.   
Once the magnets are installed,  just put a cable into the slot of the larger piece, and then snap the smaller piece onto the larger piece  to secure the button to the cable.  
If you are careful with the polarity of the  magnets (making sure each button has a north pole on one side and a south pole on the other) then you can stack the buttons on top of one another.

title: Prusa i3 MK8 heavy duty Mount with 18 mm probe mount

description.text:
Couldn't find a probe mount that satisfied my needs for this mount i like to use. So I remixed my own. I have printed it already, but did not install it yet. I also have a few more ideas how to improve this mount. This version is for 18mm probe. UPDATE 26.01.2016
And once again: DON'T PRINT THAT YET! I have dimensioned the cable slots a little too less. Have to improve it. UPDATE 25.01.2016
v1.1: Worked a little bit on a way to lead the cables of motor, heater and thermistor in a more cleaner way.
Warning: I did not print and test it yet. Feel free to be faster than me and post your result in the comments. UPDATE 21.01.2016
Here we go! v1.0.1 has been printed and tested. The first issues are fixed. I used 30% infill, to get a faster printout, but that's definitely too less. The probe holder broke off with the first touch and I had to stick the parts together with Aceton / ABS mixture.
The first printout was filled 100% and rigid as hell. So feel free to test and post your settings and results in the comments.
Upcoming features: Compact cable management and maybe some illumination. UPDATE 20.01.2016
Dont't print that yet! Tried to install it yesterday evening and had problems getting the motor into it. Have to fine tune some details.

author: JPlaysMCLolz

title: A new printer IdeaLab One 3d printer

description.text:
My goal was to create a desktop 3D printer which is safe for the user and release an open source license. My son is 15 months and loves to watch the printer working, however, the RepRap construction design and the fact that it is open, exposes him to potential burns and cuts. The risk was too great so I decided to base the design on the cover which will protect the user from injury. After more than a year of work I am pleased to release the project in Beta version. The files are now available and currently I am finishing set-up instructions for my printer which will be published soon. Technical Data Size 410mm width 300 mm depth and 356mm of height
Electronics Teensylu with stepsticks
Materials ABS and PLA (heated bed)
24V power supply
200mm width 150 depth and 150 mm height of work space
1.75 mm direct drive extruder Recently, a prototype has been built which was tested and the print quality turned out to be very good without days of calibrating it. Campaign is there you can check photos http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/idea-lab-one-open-source-3d-printer/x/4179243 On campaign there are available a CNC cutted parts for printer Assembly manual will be available before end of weeeknd

author: sharck

description.text:
Two models of spherical joints. Both are printed with PLA natural (no pigments, better resistance) with a 0.6 nozzle (stronger than 0.4mm) at 0.4mm layer heights, and using a raft to avoid squishing the bottom layer.

  • v2b - Has a very little backlash (near to none, got no tool to measure that) and very smooth movements; pull resistance 7+ Kg (first test went to 10Kg, max force depends on how you restrain it, and the wear, so taking the worst value i got ;-) )

  • v3 - noticable backlash (maybe 0.5mm), and less smooth operation; pull resistance: couldnt break it, stopped at 14Kg
    • Pull test videos
    v2b : https://youtu.be/2jcAdBitODs
    v3 : https://youtu.be/yTxLO64AOfc

Aux battery pack for all your USB powered gadgets. A group of friends and I go hiking every year and I like to plot our trips using the GPS in my phone and the Google Tracks application. Trouble is 6+ hours of full time GPS use tends be a major drain to the battery. In previous years I had purchased commercial versions similar to this, they only lasted about a year, and were not as high capacity as I was able to build here. I found that I was able to keep my phone running for about two and a half days with this battery pack. Battery - http://www.sparkfun.com/products/8484
Charger/Booster - http://www.sparkfun.com/products/10300

Print all three parts. Mark and drill the holes to hold the charger/booster circuit.
Drill out the holes for the two sides. --I found that the sides printed better raft-less when the screw holes didn't go all the way through. I had intended to use the on board micro USB socket for charging and connect a the female end of a USB extension cable for discharging. Trouble is over time the on board micro USB socket broke off.... :( so I ended up soldering in both the male and female ends of the USB cable. Assemble, Charge... Discharge... At some point I need to add a switch between the battery and the charge/boost circuit. If I understand correctly, the charge/boost circuit has a constant draw that will eventually drain the battery.

I've bought some used 12 V compressors on eBay (probably made for Aquariums?).
They are sold as "370 Mini Air Pump". This is a suitable casing for this compressor. Print two parts of this and use 4 x M3 screws and nuts to assemble. Source files available - created with Blender, using my BlenderSCAD extension (https://github.com/miguelitoelgrande/BlenderSCAD) Have fun!
Vintage car model, the Skjervold.

title: Replacment components for a Holiday Accent 7 Foot Ferris Wheel

description.text:
3d printing saves christmas!!!
My friend Randy has the largest christmas light display in Vancouver, WA and one of the star attactions is a large Holliday Accent brand 7 Foot Ferris Wheel . Unfortunatly this last display season, a windstorm did catestropic damage to this unit, Luckily, we were able to piece together enough of the shattered remnants to get good measurements off of everything, and recreate the hub, support arms, and character mount pegs.
I realize it's a longshot that anyone else will have a use for these parts, but theres always a chance!

To be used with Thinkyheads' Prusa i3 Wades Adapter:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58451 I have designed this fan-shield specifically for use with the J-head and a 30mm fan. Currently I am still improving small parts of the object so stay tuned!
In the end, this cooling shield should also be compatable with other extruder adapters that use a J-head, because the spacing of the mounting-holes is universal. Printed it myself and for me it worked flawlessly after the first try!
BUT, there are still a few design considerations I want to apply to the object, and I have to fix three small errors, but they are so small that they won't really interfere with the functioning of the thing. Still a work in progress, I just got Rhino working a few hours ago and this is my first design, I have no experience in Rhino so it took me some time to understand basics just by doing. All tips are welcome! :) Last, this is a Work in Progress, I am still tweaking my design a bit and have to make different approaches to how the air-flow will work the best and make everything actually fit well together.

So this one is for all you tech geeks out there. It's important to work out if you have your nose down a DIY projekt all day or sits in front of your 3Dprinter twenty four seven. Your body can match your brain. ;-) The Skin fold caliper is a device which measures the thickness of a fold of your skin with its underlying layer of fat. By doing this at the key locations can be a quite accurate representative of the total amount of fat that is on your body, it is also possible to estimate the total percent of body fat on your body. If you have a smartphone download this app https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=m2m.bcf (it's the best i have tried so far) and start measuring. As a fitness freak this is a real booster. title: Semi rigid UHF dipole SMA mount.

description.text:
Used to provide a mounting point for the counterpoise of a dipole.
Use 1.2mm derailleur cable for each element and cut to 158mm. For the driven element, this dimension is from the point where the cable leaves the end of the shield. The counterpoise should be soldered as close to the top of the SMA shield as possible, it helps to file a bit of material away before soldering.
Once the cables are soldered, slip the thing over the counterpoise and glue it to the SMA socket with ca glue, it helps to file a little away from the sides of the SMA plug to get a good glue joint.

A case for earbud type headphones with a cable winding system. 
Simply insert your earbuds, close the lid and wind the cable in using the free spinning wheel mounted within the lid. Finally, push the jack into the clip, and throw it in your bag or pocket for safe and stylishly contained earbuds!
Suitable for earbuds with or without an inline control. 
02/10/2016 - Revision 2 added - features less parts for easier printing!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Mini-Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: Lid: The lid will need support for the catch and hinge mounts. Print it upside down for a smooth topside. Case bottom: Support should be used for the catch mounts. Hub and nut: No support required. Winding Wheel: No support required. The catch and hinge assemblies are small and may require a raft if printing in Nylon based filaments as I did. 02/10/2016 - Revision 2 added which has inbuilt hinges and catches. The separate part versions started to break after a few months of use, so I decided to make them part of the solid.

Assembly Print the parts in your choice of material - I choose Taulman3d T-Glase for the examples in the photos. For the catches and hinge assembly I used Taulman3d Alloy 910 to give me lots of strength and a bit of flexibility. I've also printed these in both PLA and ABS for all parts with no issues.

  • Install the hub into the bottom base - it should click into place on the retainer and spin freely.

  • Push the hub post into the hole of the winding wheel - it should spin freely, and not catch on the thread of the hub post. If it does, remove some material from the centre hole of the winding wheel until it spins freely. The winding wheel teeth should point downwards, and the indent in the top of the hub post in the opposite direction to the teeth.

  • Insert the hub post with the indent at the top, into the lid and screw it in until its solidly mounted - leave around 3mm poking out - when operating the winding wheel, you will rest your thumb in the indent.

  • Screw the flat nut onto the hub, trapping the wheel in the middle. Ensure that the wheel spins freely, and once you're happy that nothing will fall out, put a dab of Superglue over the nut where it meets with the hub post.
    Gorilla Superglue works well with Taulman3D materials although it takes a few hours to fully cure - warning: It will stay wet for at least 3 hours, so don't move the part until it's cured!

  • Attach the two catches on either side at the front of the lid, and the larger hinge part on the rear of the lid. Again, Superglue will make this very durable. (Not required for revision 2)

  • Once the glue has set on the lid parts, place the lid on the case bottom and line up the catches with the posts on the case bottom.

  • Using some solid wire (I cut a leg off a resister), push the wire through the small hinge mounts with the larger hinge part in between them. Make a very small loop on either end to stop it falling out.

  • Glue the two hinge mounts either side of the larger hinge part, making sure you DO NOT glue the larger hinge part to either the mounts or the case bottom. (Not required for revision 2)

  • Choose the best place to mount the headphone jack clip and glue into place. Please refer to the pictures for my suggestions depending on the type of jack. (Not required for revision 2)
    • Scaling: The model as is in the STLs will accommodate most types of earbuds, however it can be scaled down as much as 30-35% for smaller sets.
    If you use earbuds with an inline control, such as the ones shown in the pictures, the standard STL size is about as small as you can get away with. The larger Green/Red version is scaled up by 17% to accommodate a very large in-line control used on my Sennheiser earbuds. This is still small enough to fit into a coat pocket. Revision 2 is scaled to 15% of the original size - I've found this to be the most versatile size without it becoming too bulky. A couple of points if you decide to re-scale:
  • I only scaled in the X/Y direction so that the case didn't get too bulky.
  • Don't rescale the jack clip unless your jack measures much greater than 6.3mm on the plastic housing. (Not required for revision 2) This measurement using Alloy910 gives me enough flex to push the jack in and still have it hold firm.

title: Pen plotter adapter for Replicator Dual

description.text: Pen adapter to fit the carriage of a Replicator Dual (or clone) in place of the extruders. Can take 2 pens or pencils for ditto drawing.

Instructions Fit a pen or pencil into the holder using one of the spare bolts that came with the Replicator. It should protrude about the same amount as the extruder head does (about 27mm on my machine). Remove the extruder heads and replace them with the pen adapter, securing the adapter using the same bolts. Make sure the vertical wall will make contact with the X-axis endstop to prevent the stepper motor over running. Level the build plate again to ensure the pen doesn't scratch the build plate. Instead of checking that the paper slides between the pen and the plate just make sure it's leaving a good mark. To create gcode to print from, you can import an SVG file into Blender, extrude the curves to 0.1mm, then export to STL and slice using a 0.1mm layer height. Or, use the Inkscape > OpenSCAD extension to do something similar. You can also generate your own gcode; eg "G1 X0 Y0" to move to 0mm, 0mm (the center of the build platform), "G1 Z2" to lift the pen 2mm off the page, "G1 Z0" to press it into the paper. You can vary the pen pressure by controlling the Z height to create shading - the example photograph was made using this method. SVGs plotted in pencil and ballpoint pen JPEG plotted with pencil pressure varying according to pixel brightness

title: 15mm Camera rail adapter for DSLR rig

description.text: I recently broke one of the hand grip 15mm rail adapters on my DSLR rig, before I spent $60 on a replacement I thought I'd see if I could print out a replacement. I also added a cold shoe adapter to the top of the hand grip. This makes it easy to add a shock mount, LED light, or any other random film gear to the top of the handle. I designed this around the left over parts from my original handle which used 1/4 20 square nuts and thumb screws. Square nuts are kind of hard to come by so you might want to modify this to use hexagon shaped nuts instead. The design is just small enough to fit on a TOM heated build platform (105mm), be sure to turn the outline plugin off. Over all the design feels very solid but I might add a little more plastic to the thumb nut area, unfortunately this would make it to large of an object to be printed on the HBP. So I'll probably end up printing the updated version on my Reprap. Update: The file labeled V2 has more plastic around the rail clamps and is to large to be printed on the TOM. The picture of version 2 has a green background and was printed on the Makergear Prusa. More info on all kinds of camera related stuff at DSLRFILMNOOB.com
Print it out, add a handle, square nuts, and thumb screws. Attach it to your camera rig and start filming.

title: Bicycle stem plate with GoPro mount

description.text:
Work In Progress - this is published to discuss the idea. This is the plate that tightens the bars to the stem of a mountain bike.
It has a a GoPro mount for your light, camera or similar. Flip it upside down if you like, use the loop to attach a security strap. Disclaimer: This has not been checked/calculated for strength, would advice to triple check safety, fit and dimensions before using. Based on files:
  • https://grabcad.com/library/bicycle-stem--2
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62800
Merge of two other models This is a simple mockup/merge of two other models whipped together in the Windows 10 supplied "3D builder" app.

comments.text: Well, there it is - http://www.vitalmtb.com/news/press-release/Introducing-the-PNW-Components-Range-Stem-w-GoPro-or-Garmin-faceplate-mount,1801
comments.author: ccondrup

comments.text: Yikes. I wouldnt take this on a real trail. One or two of those mount holes break and youre going to have a bad day.
comments.author: Acidrain69

comments.text:
Valid point, this is truly a WIP and I'm no engineer - just showing off an idea. There should probably be more material arount the stem bolts than this model had.
That said, you would have this plate in alu/steel and connect a plastic gopro rod to it, right - wouldn't that rod be the weak link which breaks in a crash?
comments.author: Acidrain69

comments.text: Sure, but better your gopro falls off than you lose control of the bike because the handlebars came loose. This replaces the metal holding the bars down, right? If one or two of the bolt holes crack or the hole piece splits in that thin area at the top, it's going to lose grip on the bars and potentially have them fall off the front of the bike. Then you can't steer. Yeah, if you mill this in aluminum it would probably be fine. Better to just mount the gopro around the stem and not interfere with the integrity of critical bike parts.
comments.author: ccondrup

description.text:
Similar to other ones I made,
but more reinforced so less flexing with heavy tablets.

The winners prize! A CO2 dragster designed with printing scaffolding in solid works, saved as an STL, and printed using makerbot and glow in the dark PLA is increase the cool factor. This car will race head to head against other student designed and built cars. In this unit students learned about Newton’s laws F=MA and Action reaction concepts, principles of aerodynamics, and design/engineering. They aspire to design the winning dragster using solid works and constructing their vehicles either by printing on a makerbot or more traditionally from a block of wood in the shop. (More kids could print their cars faster if we were to win a printer hint hint ) They will finish this unit in attempt to put up the fastest time in school using a track that measures to the thousandth of a second. The student with the fastest car wins this car as their trophy. ( Yes back to the ole days of racing for pink slips!)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: Standard Settings worked great on both car and Wheels.
The scaffolds made in SolidWorks are made so they are 0.003" lower than the bottom of the car. This allows them to be knocked off using a putty knife without damaging the car or our fingers.

I am a Middle School Technology education teacher in Green Bay, Wisconsin. Every year we have a unit where we have students build CO2 Dragsters. The students are Frontloaded with knowledge about aerodynamics, Newton's laws, design concepts, and a basic knowledge of Solid Works. In this unit they get to experience concepts to design and design into prototypes they will actually get to race in competition with each other. This year we borrowed a makerbot 3d printer from our art department and are experimenting with a whole new level of possibilities in car and wheel design.

Project: CO2 Dragsters Project: CO2 Dragsters
o Objectives: Upon completing this project students will:
Have an understanding in Newton’s theory’s
an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion until acted upon by an outside force Force = Mass X Acceleration ( Inverse relationship For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction (action reaction engine)
Have designed a CO2 dragster in SolidWorks
Have built the physical car using tools and machines safely and/or technology like a 3 d printer
Have raced a CO2 Dragster in friendly competition with classmates o Audiences: This project is done at the middle school level with 7th and 8th grade mixed classes o Preparation: Students need to be frontloaded with how to use solid works or another 3d modeling program. o Steps! I start with lecture on Newton’s Laws, aerodynamics, and design for manufacturability concepts. Students then research (internet and hand sketch an Idea) Once approved they may Design the car in Solidworks and print out a 1:1 scale Orthographic drawing. Students may then Print approved cars with a the printer.
o Results: At the end of this project students will have reached all objectives, They Assemble wheels(Also can be printed) and Axles and Race! As a formal assessment students are to write instructions (as if they were explaining to someone who has never designed a car before) step by step as to how to build their car.

description.text: These are 3D temple pieces for the board game Tikal, improved for better fit. description.text: These are Stacker Plates for the Keshe Magrav Power Unit. Print one top and two centre and bottom plates as well as a set of feet to form the three level stack. UPDATE: The Magrav Blueprint does not stipulate the size of the GANS ball. If the rest of the design is in line with the Blueprint, it allows for a ball with a diameter of about 20mm. V6 files have a GANS ball of 20mm and each layer has a height of 2,5cm exactly in line with the Blueprint and should stack perfectly. If you prefer the larger GANS ball of 40mm - ping-pong ball size, then use the V4 files which should stack taller. Important: Ensure the inner coil has 81 turns, with a 1mm gap between each turn and the outer coil has 144 turns with a 1mm gap between each turn. Use cable-ties to keep everything in place if required. All the parts can be glued together to finalize the assembly. Please consult the Keshe Foundation Website and the Magrav Blueprints for more information on making the coils and the GANS. Available on shapeways:https://www.shapeways.com/product/85CK3LASR/magrav-stacker-plate-centre-and-bottom

This is a "useless box". If you're unfamiliar with them, they are basically just a fun project to make and serve no purpose other than to turn themselves off when you turn them on. See the video for demonstration. First... I should say that there are probably better boxes on this site... Please edit this in Autodesk 123D Design before making one! The STL provided is for display only, do not attempt to print this as 1 piece.
The files will likely need adjustment depending on how your printer works.. do some test slices. I had to do some sanding/filing to make it all fit together nicely. I'm sharing the 123D files so that any adventurous tinkerers out there can edit the design to suit their needs or use as inspiration for their own project... this isn't a "turnkey" print! :) 1) The motor stand will need to be adjusted if you use a different diameter motor than I did
2) I sanded/filed some things quite a bit after printing. I've adjusted some of the things I sanded, but have not printed another to test fit!
3) I'd recommend slicing it up and printing parts to make sure things fit for you. Mine works awesome... here's a vid:
https://youtu.be/hSis44Rbxic

comments.text: is it printed as one piece?
comments.author: CaplingerAlex

comments.text: No, sorry, this isn't a 1 piece print.  There are 4 different pieces in the .123dx file and it may require some modification to suit your needs.  It's definitely a fun project, but depending on the parts you use (switch, motor) it can be very advanced.

title: K8400 Vertex bottom dual fan duct

description.text: Recreated the bottom fan duct to also blow to the second extruder driver.
Rotate -90 degrees around X-axis (fan mount to bed) and print with supports to the bed. Removing the support is a pain!
Print the seperated parts with no support and glue them together. (I did not try this, but as far I've seen with my print, this should work.)

Printer:

Vertex

Infill:

20%

Assembly For better airflow cut the ribbon cable in the middle (use a dull tool, e.g. screwdriver) and place it between the motor drivers. (optionally) Fasten the fan with the original screws which held it at the bottom of the printer. I used a screwdriver to block the nut from rotating and holding it in place at the tricky spot. Replace the original spacers below the board with the assembled fan duct. Place the ribbon cable in the notch. Use the original screws. Use two cable ties to fasten the fan duct, one from each side. Bend the one from the bottom a little bit so it slides into the hole.

description.text:
Its here- The second half of my full body 3D scanning setup is ready to be shared with the world! Building upon my Scan-O-Tron Turntable v.2.0 for Full Body 3D Scanning (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:729923 ), this 3D Scanning rig greatly improves the quality of full body scans captured with a Microsoft Kinect using ReconstructMe or Skanect software. I have scanned over 5000 people with this rig (in groups from 1-4 people) and get consistently great results that can be cleaned up in just moments using Netfabb basic. In additions to the instructions posted here, you can also see Make Magazine's project build instructions here:
http://makezine.com/projects/guide-to-3d-printing-2014/scan-o-tron-3000/ BOM on Inventables (I earn 10% royalties if you buy your materials from this link, so please support the project by buying your parts here):
https://www.inventables.com/projects/the-scan-o-tron-3000-full-body-3d-scanner Kickstarter Campaign

This thing was published as the culmination of my Coney Island Scan-A-Rama Kickstarter campaign http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/fredini/coney-island-scan-a-rama Special thanks to our open Hardware Backers: Rachel Uwa, Chris Thorpe, Chee Yue, Matt Griffin, Marco Barnig, Paul R, Theron, Trowbridge, Dillon Zwick, John Dimatos, B Alan Eisen, Seth Madej, Tony Buser, Bridget Dearborn, Victor Bourdon, Sergey Key, Nick Blackledge, Opal Lechmanski, Mike and Brenda Sessums, Gael Langevin, Marianne R. Petit, RFimages, Britt, solids2go.com, Mike Kaltschnee, Edith Harari, Ross Tsukashima, and more. Video link: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6eKOEgXxdUw
Video link: http://youtu.be/9ZVc-CpVLrs

See the Make Magazine project build instructions here:
http://makezine.com/projects/guide-to-3d-printing-2014/scan-o-tron-3000/ BOM:

I bought my materials from Inventables. The list of hardware is listed on their site with one click to add it to your shopping cart ( I earn 10% if you buy your materials from this link):
https://www.inventables.com/projects/the-scan-o-tron-3000-full-body-3d-scanner Additionally, you will need:
  • 1- 1/4" threaded rod, washers and nuts
    -ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ 2x 2 1/2" clothesline pulleys
    http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-2-1-2-in-White-Clothesline-Pulley-14062/202305414#.Uf8EPWn724R
  • 1 empty filament spool
    -ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ 1 cabinet knob
  • 1 length of twine
  • 2 skateboard bearings
    • Assembly Instructions:

1) Print parts- I printed mine 100% solid. You will need 2 makerslide endcaps
2) Assemble the two 3D printed parts of the hinge- I used a piece of 3mm filament as the pin.
3) Glue together the two parts of the guillotine drop piece and place it on the hinge.
4) Drill the back of the smaller hinge part and bolt it to the carriage plate
5) Splice the 1800mm and a 600mm section of Makerslide together.
Assemble the cart
6) Cut four 200mm segments of aluminum extrusion and attach the Makerslide to the 1800mm piece of extrusion using the angle brackets. Fashion a base with 2 lengths of 560mm aluminum extrusions and one 46mm Extrusion.
7)Use the 2 20x20mm lengths as diagonal supports.
8) Assemble filament spool with the "bearing discs", and mount it on the threaded rod.
9) Put skateboard bearings into Rod Bearing 1 and 2, then mount them onto the extrusion at about waist height
9) Mount the carriage on the vertical rail and attach the string on it.
10) Put the endcaps on the tops of the rig and then put the clothesline pulleys in them. Thread the string over the top of the rig and back down to the filament spool.
11) Put several rubberbands around the two sides of the hinges and mount the kinect onto the hinge (yes its a little frankenstein, but I am using rubberbands to mount the kinect here. I will update this part soon with a more graceful solution) You are now ready to begin scanning. The video should get you started. Look for updates to this project coming soon.

description.text: This is a model of a duck I made to learn to use the sculpting. It is my first attempt. I believe I will work on it more to make it more realistic and detailed.
This model was made by using the sculpting mode. I use the Fusion 360 software.

The Pattern builder helps children learn essential building blocks of beginning math. By manipulating the tiles, children will gain a better understanding of patterns in Math and their world around them.

Project: Pattern Builder Objectives:Students will gain an understanding of patterns in Math and in their world as well. Audiences Audiences: The pattern builder is great for kids in preschool and kindergarten as well as for special needs children. Preperation Preparation: 2 sets of slides and patterns should be printed. The instructor may build a pattern to serve as a visual aid or he or she may just verbally instruct the child on what to do. Results After printing the pattern builder you will have made a slide to hold pattern tiles as well as a set of tiles for manipulating on the slide. print_settings.Notes:: I found the cylinder printed better when it was orintated front to back in the machine.

description.text: I am a Technology education teacher in Green Bay Wi. This is an engineering project I came up with to be done with a group of kids afterschool. Students are taught the fundamentals of designing with solid works. They then divide the work up, and work in teams of two to develop cylinder, piston flywheel, and supports with in parameters set up by the teacher. Students can finish their designs and assemble the parts in solidworks as a group. ( there is a fair amount of reworking/ problem solving at this phase). Once the designs are reworked approved the students save them as stl files and print all the parts. The can assemble the engine fitting parts and lubricating. Then its test time! Which then again leads back to problem solving and reworking some parts. Some instances frustration but hey that’s why they call it a prototype! If it’s easy you’re not learning! (In this case we Reworked the cylinder 3 times and its support twice) This is a great way to take students though the design process. They get to see an idea become a drawing and eventually using their problem solving skills, persistence and a little luck they see a product that works

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: Standard settings printed well.
  • I found the cylinder printed better when it was orintated front to back in the machine.

Putting it all together The motor was assembled with about $2 dollars in hardware (list below). You may need to ream out bolt/cylinder holes with corresponding drill bits and lightly sand piston. I lubricated the engine with a light grease. We used some scrap wood for the base. I also used two part epoxy glue to glue the flywheel and Piston support into the anchor blocks (Again scrap pieces of wood with a groove and screw holes cut) To give the flywheel some weight it needs for inertia to do its thing I pressed 4 pennies into each of the flywheels 8 holes using a small c clamp. If you copy and paste this link you can see the motor running https://drive.google.com/file/d/0ByqQhIB1DIDDWUpRMzdRclRZUVk/view?usp=sharing Hardware List

1/4" fender washer
3/4"x1" spring
Hex bolt 3/8" x 2.5
3/8" lock nut (plastic insert kind)
(3) 3/8" washer
Hex bolt 1/4" x 2"
1/4" lock nut
(2) 1/4" washers
1/4" x1/2" nylon spacer (this part could be printed if you designed it)
32 shiny copper pennies (They dont really have to be shiney)

This motor was designed on solidworks, assembled in solidworks (pictured below), and converted to an STL. We then Printed each peice and assembled as described to "Post Printing". During this process there was alot of Problem solving as described in the summary. In the end this is an excellent project to take a small group of students though the design process.

Project: Air Engine o Objectives: Upon completion on this projects students will:
  • Be able to work in a small group to accomplish a goal.
  • Be able to identify, explain and experience the steps of the Design process.
  • Be able to read a plan, design the part, and assemble the engine
  • Be able to trouble shoot and brainstorm solutions if their engine doesn’t work.
    • o Audiences: This would be an advanced 7-8 grade after-school small group activity. Or an entry level Engineering Coarse for 9-12 grade. o Preparation: Students should have good foundational knowledge in Solidworks (or like program i.e. Inventor). Students should have an understanding of how this air engine works. (power/exhaust stroke) o Steps! I would have lecture/discussion on the Design Process. After check of understanding I would break the students into sub groups (2-4) Students would receive Plans for the engine and break up the work evenly. When all parts are made on the computer students would assemble the separate parts as a group. As a group they would check clearances and position of the valves etc. They may have to do some brainstorming to fix any potential problems. Students would Print and assemble their Physical engine Test and evaluate. Depending on their outcome they may need to re-engineer some parts till it works.
    Enrichment #1 have student build the engine from a physical model previously made. They would have to measure the parts and then build them from their own measurements Enrichment #2 Students can build the motor off your plans but they need to change the bore and stroke.
    o Results: At the end of this project each group will have a motor that runs. Students can take a video of the running motor. They can then explain their experiences in the steps of the design process that lead them to success. This could be done in a typed or video format.

comments.text: Thank-you for the compliments. Its truly is a neat and inexpensive way to prototype designs. It gets the students excited about designing parts that become tangible "rewards".

I don't know how to use a lathe or how to weld and a bunch of other things, but I can still go through the entire process of concept, design, manufacturing, testing, redesign, re-manufacture, retest over and over again very cheaply at my own desk.  Eventually you end up with a product that your really proud of.

description.text:
This is the first iteration (third internal) of my attempt to make printable Velcro. It is pretty nice to hang things, probably this small piece will resist much more than a kilogram of weight (hanging weight) and it is very easy to remove. 3d printing revolution is just starting, I don't say this is a flawless piece but I really consider it is a very good example about a very sweet future about us modifying our brains from "search-buy-adapt" (frustration included) to "think-design-print" (self-pride included :D ). Quick demo video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BtLSMI3xVDY
Quick demo #2 (perpendicular): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eLehgIfjmpA This was an object that did not exist in our 3d printing world, so I like to think this is an "upgrade" from real world to a better virtual&teleportable world ;)

• Print (I used 0.3 mm layer height, natural 3 mm abs, MK6, 100% fill)
  • There may be some bridges because printing limitations, I used the included blade with my TOM kit to clean a bit the pieces
  • Use it!

comments.text: I tried 3 different slicing programs: Skeinforge 39, Slic3r, and Kisslicer with my Solidoodle at 0.3mm layer height. The best results were with Slic3r, with a near perfect print. Kiss came in 2nd place. It did a couple funky things that made a bad spot on one piece, but it still worked and sliced it in a reasonable amount of time (actually the fastest, under 1min!). Skeinforge took over an hour to create the Gcode and printed the bumps in an uneven diagonal pattern (looked just like the pics above) which rendered it unusable.

description.text:
I needed a Headphone Stand which I could clamp between my desk and it's substructure. Couldn't find one - designed it myself. Two M3 Screws are required. Nuts shouldn't be needed. The Plastik should work just fine as a thread. BE AWARE:
This is a real "Quick'n'Dirty"-Job. It took me an hour to design. It's the worst code I ever wrote. (Would have probably been faster to just write nice code...)
So if you want to customize it - you can, but the scad file comes without any warranties. Good luck!
(Hint: to modify the thickness of the clamp you have to edit the mount module.) If there is any real demand i would probably write some nice code... but since there are plenty headphone stands to choose from I don't suppose this one will be particularly popular.

Hello
Here is a lampshade, to suspend origamis. in this example, flying birds will make some nice shadows on the walls...

As the circle is quite large (25 cm of diameter), you have to print four times a quarter, and then assemble them.
You can glue the lampshade parts with either a bit of Aceton (will dissolve the ABS and glue the different parts) or cyanoacrylat (usual super-glu). It might be needed to re-drill the holes for the strings, depending on the quality of the printer. The support can be fixed on the ceiling with 2 screws. It has small slots to pass the strings on which the origamis are attached.

A simple, freestanding and adjustable camera mount for the Raspberry Pi camera. Only requires 4 M2 bolts and some nuts, and the different slots allow you to angle it differently according to your needs. No glue or anything required. A part of my "Switch" project that I worked on last year with the goal of creating a modular camera system for the Raspberry Pi. While I had more planned, its just not practical for me to keep going for now, so I'm hoping the community will take what I've started and make it a reality. More parts are in my gallery. The idea was to create a system of parts that could be used more or less interchangeably with each other, allowing people to make a rig as big or small as they wanted, in a format that suited their needs. UPDATES:
2016-02-24: Updated the SVG file. It is much easier and nicer to work with now. Also added instruction image.

title: Insert for Shower Handle Knob to grip valve stem

description.text:
My shower knob stopped working because it was made of polyacrylic and had to grip onto a brass valve stem. Over time, the teeth of the plastic shower handle wore off because the brass was much harder. This insert replaces the teeth on the inside so that the knob will once again grip the valve stem. It has twelve teeth, about 30 degrees apart, with about 8.65 mm inner diameter and about 9.6 mm outer diameter. The outside of the part is 10mm in diameter so that a new knob can be drilled out of an existing object with a 10 mm drill bit.
I have also provided a temporary shower knob which I used to prototype the inner gear-teeth.
